titleStmt.title: The tragedy of Gray-Beard or The brandybotle of Kinkegolaw: With an answer to Mr. Guild's vindication of the brandy-bottle of Kinkegolaw, which is not here mentioned. Being the tragedy of the Duke de Alva, alias Gray-beard, or The complaint of the brandy bottle, lost by a poor carriour by falling from the handle, and found by a company of the Presbitery of Peebles near to Kinkegolaw, as they returned from Glasgow, immediately after they had taken the Test.
titleStmt.author: Pennecuik, Alexander, 1652-1722.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE TRAGEDY OF GRAY-BEARD OR THE BRANDY BOTLE OF KINKEGOLAW:
With an An≈øwer to Mr. Guild's Vindication of the Brandy-Bottle of Kinkegolaw, which is not here mentioned.

Being the Tragedy of the Duke de Alva, alias Gray-beard, or the Complaint of the Brandy Bottle, lo≈øt by a poor Carriour by falling from the Handle, and found by a Company of the Presbitry of Peebles near to Kinkegolaw, as they returned from Gla≈øgow, immediatly after they had taken the Te≈øt.

div.head: The Tragedy of the Duke de Alva, alias Gray-Beard, or the Complaint of the Brandie Bottle, lo≈øt by a poor Carriour by falling from the Handle, and found by a Campany of the Presbytery of Peebles near to Kinkegolaw, as they returned from Gla≈øgow, immediatly after they had taken the Te≈øt.
div.l: IT fell upon the Moneth of November,
A fatal Fall my Bodie did Di≈ømember:
Many ≈øhall tell the Tale that never ≈øaw,
The Brandy-Bottle of Kinkegolaw.
Where groaning on the ground I chanc'd to ≈øpy
Two Men in Black devoutly pa≈ø≈øing by;
So when my feeble voice their ears could reach
Poor antient Gray-beard thus began to preach
O Sons of Levi, Mini≈øters of Grace,
Have ≈øome regard to my right reverend Face;
My broken Shoulders, and my wrinkled Brow,
Calls fa≈øt for Pity and Supply from you;
Help, Godly Sirs, and if it be your Will,
Convey me ≈øafely Home to Bigger-Mill;
Where going to the Widow I was lo≈øt,
Alas! I fear the Carriour pay the co≈øt.
Poor Soul, if this mi≈øchance ≈øhould him betide,
He has no more in all the World be≈øide.
They did not reli≈øh this Di≈øcour≈øe of mine,
But vow'd the poor ≈øhould ≈øoon be out of pine;
And took me Pri≈øoner to Kinkegolaw
Where ≈øtore of that Black Company I ≈øaw:
Fy Sirs, ≈øaid I you have at Gla≈øgow, been,
Swearing Alledgeance to your God and King;
So do not ≈øuperad ≈øo foul a Deed,
And take poor Gray-beard's blood upon your head,
This cruelty ≈øore ≈øhould you all repent,
Were he but here who≈øe Picture I pre≈øent,
And yet before we part, I'll ≈øo prevail,
The be≈øt of you ≈øhall ≈øtrive to ki≈øs my Tail,
This I was taught when Gray beard I was call'd
That proper, pure religion, and undefil'd;
The Widows Ca≈øe and Fatherle≈øs did notice,
And ne'r drank out, but filld their empty botles
At fir≈øt they pitied my Lifele≈øs Skin,
But when they found ≈øome cordial heat within
They flock'd about & quickly me ≈øurrounded
And cruelly unto the Heart me wounded:
They ≈øaid de Alva never took the Te≈øt,
Therefore rank Papi≈øt go unto thy re≈øt;
And brag of thy right honourable Tomb:
When thou art buri'd in a Te≈øters Womb,
Right blyth they were & drank to one anoth ‚Ä¢
And ≈øtill th'health went round, here to you br ‚Ä¢ th ‚Ä¢
I love thy blood ≈øo well ≈øays Ma≈øter Boe,
Thy Bones to Tweed ≈øhall in Proce≈ø≈øion go,
At la≈øt the Ho≈øtes of the Hou≈øe came in,
Finding the Brethren in a merry pin,
She tells them that a Carriour poor had lo≈øt;
The Brandy-Botle whereof they did boa≈øt;
And for a ≈øure unque≈øtionable Token,
Here is the hand look ye where it was broke ‚Ä¢
So grave and reverend Sirs be but ≈øo hand≈øome
To take a double Gill for Gray-breads ran≈øom ‚Ä¢
At which their godly Wi≈ødoms were confoun ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢
For they had no intention to refound it.

div.head: Mr. P. Purdy Speaks.
div.l: Yet one ≈øtood up in Name of all the re≈øt,
And ≈øwore he bought it when he took the Te≈øt
So be he Poor or Rich the Brandy lo≈øt,
Till Doom≈øday we ≈øhall never pay the co≈øt.
This Wife wil Lodge none be it Paul or Peter
If once they take the te≈øt, for fear they cheat her
You ≈øhall not find a Cloy≈øter of ≈øuch Clouns,
Search all the Squads of Troupers or Dragouns
Survey the Country, try the Broken Lairds,
Search Mar & Lithgows regiments of guards)
Such ≈øprit Liquor cures Us of all Sorrow;
Courage we'll take another Te≈øt to Morrow:
And after all is done, we can Recant,
And ≈øwear to Tenor, Te≈øt or Covenant:
While we are here, we'll no Advantage ≈øhun,
There is no Brandy in the World to come,

div.head: An An≈øwer to Mr. Guild's Vindication.
div.l: ‚Ä¢ nfamous Scribler, Natures Fool and Shame!
O ≈øen≈øele≈øs Satyre, Bea≈øt without a Name;
Thou ≈øcandal to Devotion, ≈øcurvy Prie≈øt,
Why made thou earne≈øt of a merry Je≈øt?
Ba≈øe Ballader, had thou no Remor≈øe,
To turn poor Gray-heads Ca≈øe from bad to wor≈øe
‚Ä¢ ll my thy ≈ølanderous Tongue for ever ≈ømart,
Though it run parallel with thy fal≈øe heart,
And cudgel thy dry Carca≈øe into Tears,
Were't not for the ≈øacred Coat thou bears.
What Mortal can read manners, good or gra ‚Ä¢
In the dark Lanthern of thy Gip≈øies Face:
Thou nea≈øty Negro, filthy rea≈øty Ram,
A skin like that of a We≈øtphalia-ham;
Egyptian Mummy out of ≈øight be gone.
Let none but Surgeons view thy Scaleton.
A Female amorous that were in Love,
At thy fir≈øt view would ≈øoon abortive prove
If by misfortune ≈øhe ≈øhould chance to ≈øee,
So foul a Compound of Disformitie.
Thou calls the Author fool that never hear ‚Ä¢
How Spaniards wear Mu≈øtachoes & no beard
Ob≈øcure Phanta≈øtick Fellow let alone,
I have ≈øeen 500 Spaniards for thy one:
And yet I ≈øwear of all thy Sun-brunt Crew,
I ≈øaw not one had thy prodigious Hew:
Granting that this the Spaniards Cu≈øtom we ‚Ä¢
In every place are not ≈øome ≈øingular?
Bold Igno ‚Ä¢ amus, what needs all thir Jarrs?
Read thou but Strabo on the Belgick Wars;
Where thou wilt ≈øee D. Alvas Beard & Face,
The Dutch drew on their Bottles in di≈øgrace.
Thou Poeta≈øters Ape, ≈øtain to thy Nation
Vile Product of ≈øome mon≈øtruous Copulation
Officious Guild, where were thy Fancy brags,
When Gullen≈øtript thee from thy Lou≈øie-rags.
And wilt thou Verifie that general Evil,
Let Beggars tide, they'l gallop to the Devil.
Did this look Go≈øpel-like, Guilddar thou ≈øay't
To drink the poor Mans Bottle & not pay't
Or was it ≈øeemly for a Man that Preaches,
To ≈øteal away the Bottle in his Breeches,
Look that thy ab≈øence make the not de≈øpair,
And cut thy Throat, becau≈øe thou mi≈øt a ≈øhare
For ≈øure it was, it put the in a Rapture,
That thou forgot both Prayer, Grace & Chapter
Thy wi≈øer Brethren ≈øilent were & ≈øorrie,
Such Fools as thou do make their ≈øhame their glory
Thou wilt not have that fault ≈øo much as nam'd
Which they them≈øelves fir≈øt openlie Proclaim'd
Thine was a Raling not a Vindication,
And makes thee now Ridiculous to the Nation
Why does this Fellow thus his Follie vent
Doth Boe or He our whole Church Repre≈øent?
Among the Apo≈øtles was there not a Cheat,
And ≈øee we not the Tares grow with the What
Don't hi≈øing ≈ønaks cloud the fair gli≈øtring mo ‚Ä¢
And grow not naughtie Gull among the Cor ‚Ä¢
Clap to thy ≈øtomack this my bli≈øtring Plai≈øt ‚Ä¢
And Learn no more to meddle with thy Ma≈øt ‚Ä¢
Which if thou do, the next it will be ≈øharpe ‚Ä¢
I Fear not thee, far le≈øs Tom Suter Harper
Whom I could whip, but Credit me re≈øtrai ‚Ä¢
Becau≈øe the Fellow is not worth my pains.
Now ≈øhow thy ≈øelf great Cae≈øar Man or ni ‚Ä¢
O Guild thou fool, mock Preacher at Kirkm ‚Ä¢
